g.title: leaf_14
g.text: This is a string builder class.

g.title: leaf_23
g.text: , may be concatenated with either a string or itself,
and will eventually implement the full string library as method calls.

g.title: leaf_25
g.text: I use a definite string building paradigm for which the Phrase class is a drop-in

g.title: leaf_27
g.text: The base Phrase class is mutable. Concatenating will add to the array portion of
the Phrase. This means in normal use, once a Phrase is added to another Phrase,

g.title: leaf_41
g.text: of mutability is copy-on-write. We're not providing a mutation
interface yet, all we need is for it to behave like a string under

g.title: leaf_49
g.text: I intend to extend the class once we get to an editing environment, by making it
persistent rather than immutable. A distinction I will elucidate when I reach it.

g.title: leaf_66
g.text: elseif typica == "table" and tail_phrase.idEst == new then
return nil, "tail phrase was unsuitable for concatenation"

g.title: leaf_59
g.text: Concatenation is the frequent operation in working with Nodes. By default,
all a Node is in a position to do is yield a string. Phrase allows us to
enhance that with various table-assisted superpowers.

g.title: leaf_61
g.text: Also, Lua strings are very cheap once created. Concatenating them together in
a recursively larger pattern is really expensive by comparison, and that's
the entire paradigm of all these tools right now.

g.title: leaf_63
g.text: This and retaining the Docs in-memory will get the spring back in our step.

g.title: leaf_65
g.text: - head_phrase: This may be either a primitive string or a Phrase.
- tail_phrase: This may be either primitive or a Phrase. If head_phrase
is a string, tail_phrase is not, or we'd be in the VM.

g.title: leaf_78
g.text: s:complain("NYI", "cannot accept phrase seed of type" .. typica)

g.title: leaf_75
g.text: Treating Phrase as a string at any point should render it into one.
